Here "in the days of" is an idiom meaning "when." AT: "when Josiah son of Amon was king of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the days of Josiah son of Amon, king of Judah

contextId.information: Here "in the days of" is an idiom meaning "when." AT: "when Johoiakim son of Josiah was king of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the days of Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah

The nation is compared to a special bride in an affectionate way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "am completely angry together with Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"heavy with years" is an idiom that means "very old." It reinforces the phrase "old person." AT: "every very old person." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: every old person heavy with years

contextId.information: AT: "We are in anguish." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "the things that they do." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:01|1:2]]. AT: "the message that Yahweh spoke to Jeremiah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the word that came to Jeremiah from Yahweh

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "for that will ruin you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "where I allowed my name to stay" is an idiom that means this was a place where Yahweh was worshiped. AT: "the place in Shiloh where I first allowed my people to worship me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: my place that was in Shiloh, where I allowed my name to stay there in the beginning

contextId.information: AT: "stubbornly refused to listen." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "someday in the future." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
See how you translated "walked after" in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:23|2:23]]. AT: "and that they have faithfully obeyed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh tells what the people of Judah will say when the land is destroyed. AT: "We are very upset." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
AT: "There will be a time" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "walking" is an idiom for the way a person lives. The word "heart" is a metonym for a person's desires and emotions. AT: "Each person has refused to change and has been living by his own wicked desires" or "Each person has refused to change and continues to do the evil things that they want to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Each person has been walking in the stubbornness of his wicked heart.

contextId.information: This word is used here to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "cut him off" means to destroy him. Also, "the living" refers to living people. AT: "Let is kill him so he is no longer in the land of those who are alive" or "Let us destroy him so that he is no longer among the world of living people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: Let us cut him off from the land of the living

contextId.information: The word "year" here is a idiom that describes a specific period of time that Yahweh decides. AT: "in the time of their punishment" or "for the time of their punishment is coming" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This word is used here to draw someone's attention to what is said next. AT: "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"as surely as Yahweh is alive." The people use this expression to show that what they say next is certainly true. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Swearing in Yahweh's name instead of in Baal's name indicates that they worship Yahweh instead of Baal. AT: "I solemnly swear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:01|1:2]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke a message" or "Yahweh spoke" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:01|1:2]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke a message to me again" or "Yahweh spoke another message to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the word of Yahweh came to me again

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "who are stubborn and only do the things they desire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who walk in the hardness of their heart

"as surely as Yahweh is alive." The people use this expression to show that what they say next is certainly true. This is a way of making a solemn promise. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:12:16|12:16]]. AT: "I solemnly swear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The idiom to fill means that they have placed many idols in the land. The words "their filling" can be translated with a verbal phrase. AT: "because they have filled my inheritance with their disgusting idols" or "because their disgusting idols are everywhere in my inheritance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: for their filling my inheritance with their disgusting idols

contextId.information: AT: "to protect your lives" or "if you value your lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
